questiontext.text:
The denominator of an algebraic fraction can often be factorised into a product of linear and/or irreducible quadratic factors. Before we can separate algebraic fractions into simpler (partial) fractions we need to completely factorise the denominators into linear and irreducible quadratic factors. 

Linear factors are those of the form \(ax+b\); for example \(2x+7\), \(3x-2\) and \(4-x\). 

Irreducible quadratic factors are those of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\) such as \(x^2+x+1\), and \(4x^2-2x+3\), which cannot be factorised into linear factors (these are real quadratics with complex roots).
